channel.title: Vps buying guide
channel.description:
Guide to the world of a Virtual Private Server (Vps). Welcome to my guide on how to find a Windows or linux VPS.
Part 1: There are a lot of choices to make before deciding on your VPS. Such as what operating system do you want, how much ram/diskspace, bandwidth and Cpu you will need, Also what how much you are wanting to pay. First off we are going to talk about the operating system. There are major differences in the two operating systems you have to choose from, now keep in mind that each of these major OS's come with different versions for you to pick through to suite your needs best. My personal choice is the Windows server 2008 as It is fast, has the feel of a regular computer and is usually more secure. The same is to be said with Windows server 2003. These are the only Windows OP's I would recommend for a VPS for RsPs. Now on to Linux, Linux comes in many variations and is the #1 free OS in the world. As you have so many choices in this area it can be very confusing as to where to start. For a Linux OS I would recommend centOS. If you read below and look at my charts. I will compare the Prices, and the specs of my favorite VPS companies.
Alright here's a few slides to show some basic information, Then we get you off to the interwebz for some shopping ;D
[IMG]http://i48.tinypic.com/1564dub.png[/img] [IMG]http://i46.tinypic.com/wcjw9s.png[/img] [IMG]http://i48.tinypic.com/2dtngk7.png[/img]
Now onto where to go to check out all these bad bitches :D
[IMG]http://i49.tinypic.com/2lddts2.png[/img] [IMG]http://i49.tinypic.com/15i7n5y.png[/img] [URL=http://"http://myhosting.com"]My hosting.[/URL]
[IMG]http://i47.tinypic.com/121a938.png[/img] [URL=http://"http://www.liquidweb.com/vps/"]LiquidWeb[/URL]
[IMG]http://i46.tinypic.com/2wrdjqs.png[/img] [URL=http://"http://www.vpsland.com/vps_hosting.php"]Vpsland.[/URL]
WILL UPDATE WITH MORE INFORMATION SOON.
My personal opinions on the matters.
I personally have had experience with each of these companies and their products. This is my evaluation of their Customer support, Overall speed, and Help with problems.
Myhosting.com:
Myhosting.com is by far my favorite, They were in relatively inexpensive for the type of VPS I bought, They set it up within an hour and everything worked great. They even give you a 2 week grace period to either remove your data from the vps, or to pay your next bill. Support was fast and very effective.
Liquidweb.com:
Liquidweb.com was one of the first VPS companies I used. I started out on a linux without their 10$ support package and they still helped me as much as they possibly could. I ended up spending the 10$ and from there on out they set anything up that I asked for. Very fast service, And always a American with very great english.
Vpsland.com:
I am not a fan of vpsland, their packages are not good for running a rsps, they offer no customization as far as in the start. The Customer service is like a bunch of monkeys humping a banana (Something you don't want to deal with.)

item.title: Vps buying guide
item.dc:creator: @Sessy_Pk3r Sessy Pk3r
item.description:
@Sessy_Pk3r wrote:

2 words
staminus vps.
Simply nothing better, those vps’s mentioned earlier for 30$/m aren’t ddos protected. Which makes them worthless. For 28$ a month you get virtually the same specs AND protection from attacks.

Read full topic

[quote=“pvp007, post:1, topic:454158”]Guide to the world of a Virtual Private Server (Vps).
Welcome to my guide on how to find a Windows or linux VPS.

Part 1: There are a lot of choices to make before deciding on your VPS. Such as what operating system do you want, how much ram/diskspace, bandwidth and Cpu you will need, Also what how much you are wanting to pay.
First off we are going to talk about the operating system. There are major differences in the two operating systems you have to choose from, now keep in mind that each of these major OS’s come with different versions for you to pick through to suite your needs best. My personal choice is the Windows server 2008 as It is fast, has the feel of a regular computer and is usually more secure. The same is to be said with Windows server 2003. These are the only Windows OP’s I would recommend for a VPS for RsPs. Now on to Linux, Linux comes in many variations and is the #1 free OS in the world. As you have so many choices in this area it can be very confusing as to where to start. For a Linux OS I would recommend centOS.
If you read below and look at my charts. I will compare the Prices, and the specs of my favorite VPS companies.

Liquidweb.com:

I ended up spending the 10$ and from there on out they set anything up that I asked for. Very fast service, And always a American with very great english.

item.title: Vps buying guide
item.dc:creator: @dwarfs222 dwarfs222
item.description:
@dwarfs222 wrote:

[quote=“Samih1996, post:4, topic:454158”]this is a little stupid. if i calculate the usage of my computers electricity, in 7 days a week for “24/7” my computer can stay on and the bill will be 5.08 pounds so if we times by 4 its 20.32 pounds a month.

So what i mean is I can run a computer with power saver which will even use up less electricity with a 8GB Memory Ram with a 2.67 CPU and an ATI Premium Graphics Card. also with a 1TB disk space. OS: Windows 7 Ultimate. … I can do this for a cheaper price, and the VPS barely has any good specs.

Now why would I buy a VPS if i can pay this money for a cheaper price to my parents?[/quote]
You have a point.

Read full topic

item.title: Vps buying guide
item.dc:creator: @pvp007 pvp007
item.description:
@pvp007 wrote:

Yes, But at the same time Linux is a lot less user compatible and requires you to learn a new skill set to use it.

Read full topic

item.title: Vps buying guide
item.dc:creator: @Jaxus Jaxus
item.description:
@Jaxus wrote:

The only website I would even recommend using that appeared in your list, is MyHosting. I’ve been using them for almost a month now and I’ve had no problems. Also, if you are looking forward to have a very successful server, you might want to consider ONLY Linux based VPS since they provide better performance and flexibility for your server.

Read full topic
